Well I don't know much about anything, but I sure liked this film. In short, it was creative, humorous, simple, and heartwarming. Okay, since you're probably going to ask what the "in short" meant, I'll elaborate a bit. It was filmed with a big convex lens, which caused everything to become rounded and soft, and anything further than about three feet was seen as a diminished circle. Nothing up close was distorted though, so

I'd even say some shades of Hitchcock...this is clearly better than MMM, which is seen as a guilty pleasure by some if not most Woody fans...

"Les Valseuses" was released as a double feature film with "La Piscine" (1969) starring Alain Delon, Romy Schneider, and Maurice Ronet. If you are a fan of Zorro, Indiana Jones, or action in general this is a must-see. A woman who hates cats (Alice Krige) and her son (Brian Krause) have moved into a small town, and must deal with a mean cat haters (Deborah Odell), a handsome feller who likes cats (Cameron Dye), and the towns eccentric cat lady (Yvonne De Carlo). With guests starring Madeline Kahn and Shea Whigham.
